Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XXXVI. THE BOCHERES. Mortificacio Cristi [and burial of Jesus]. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Pilatus. Caiphas. Anna. Jesus. Maria. Johannes. Maria Cleophe. Latro a sinistris. Latro a dextris. Garcio. Miles. Longeus latus. Centerio. Joseph [of Arimathea]. Nichomedis.

[Scene I] The way before the hill of Calvary. 1. Pil. Sees, Seniours, and see what I saie, Takis tente to my talkyng enteere, Devoyde all Ã¾is dynne here Ã¾is day, And fallis to my frenschippe in feere. Sir Pilate, a Prince with-owten pere, My name is full neuenly to neuen, And domisman full derworth in dere, Of gentillest Jewry full euen Am I. Who makis oppressioun, Or dose transgressioun, Be my discressioun, Shall be demed dewly to dye. 2. To dye schall I deme Ã¾ame to dede, Ão rebelles Ã¾at rewles Ã¾ame vn-right, Who Ã¾at to ?one hill wille take heede, May se Ã¾er Ã¾e soth in his sight, Howe doulful to dede Ã¾ei are dight That liste no?t owre lawes for to lere, Lo Ã¾us be my mayne and my myght, Tho churles schalle I chasteise and cheere, Be lawe. Ilke feloune false, Shall hynge be Ã¾e halse, Transgressours als, On the crosse schalle be knytte for to knawe. 3. To knawe schall I kyntte Ã¾ame on crosse, To schende Ã¾ame with schame schall I shappe, Ther liffis for to leese is no losse, Suche tirrauntis with teene for to trappe. Ãus leelly Ã¾e lawe I vnlappe, And punyssh Ã¾ame pitously, Of Jesu I holde it vnhappe, Ãat he on yone hill hyng so hye, For gilte. His bloode to spille, Toke ye you till Ãus was youre wille Full spitously to spede he were spilte. 4. Caip. To spille hym we spake in a speede, For falsed he folowde in faie, With fraudes oure folke gan he feede, And laboured to lere Ã¾ame his laye. An. Sir Pilate, of pees we youe praye, Oure lawe was full lyke to be lorne, He saued no?t oure dere Sabott daye, And Ã¾at for to scape it were a scorne, By lawe. Pil. Sirs, be-fore youre sight, With all my myght, I examynde hym right, And cause non in hym cowthe I knawe. 5. Cay. ?e knawe wele Ã¾e cause sir in cace, It touched treasoune vntrewe, Ãe tribute to take or to trace For-badde he, oure bale for to brewe. Anna. Of japes ?itt jangelid yone Jewe, And cursedly he called hym a kyng, To deme hym to dede it is diewe, For treasoune it touches Ã¾at thyng, In dede. Caip. ?itt principall And worste of all, He garte hym call Goddes sonne, Ã¾at foulle motte hyme speede! 6. Pil. He spedis for to spille in space, So wondirly wrought is youre will, His bloode schall youre bodis enbrace, For Ã¾at haue ?e taken you till. Anna. Ãat forwarde fulfayne to fulfille, In dede schall we dresse vs be-dene, ?one losell hym likis full ille, For turned is his trantis all to teene, I trowe. Cay. He called hym kyng, Ille joie hym wring! ?a, late hym hyng, Full madly on Ã¾e mone for to mowe. 7. An. To mowe on Ã¾e moone has he mente, We! fye on Ã¾e, faitour in faye, Who trowes Ã¾ou, to Ã¾i tales toke tente. Ãou saggard, Ã¾i selffe gan Ã¾ou saie, Ãe tempill distroie Ã¾e to-daye Be Ã¾e thirde day ware done ilk-a-dele, To rayse it Ã¾ou schulde Ã¾e arraye. Loo! howe was Ã¾i falsed to feele, Foule falle Ã¾e! For thy presumpcyoune Ãou haste thy warisoune, Do faste, come doune, And a comely kyng schalle I calle Ã¾ee. 8. Cay. I calle Ã¾e a coward to kenne, Ãat meruaylles and mirakills made, Ãou mustered emange many menne, But, brothell, Ã¾ou bourded to brede. Ãou saued Ã¾ame fro sorowes Ã¾ai saide, To saue nowe Ã¾i selffe late vs see, God sonne if Ã¾ou grathely be grayde, Delyuere Ã¾e doune of Ã¾at tree Anone, If Ã¾ou be funne Ãou be Goddis sonne, We schall be bonne To trowe on Ã¾e trewlye, ilkone. 9. An. Sir Pilate, youre pleasaun[c]e we praye, Takis tente to oure talkyng Ã¾is tide, And wipe ?e yone writyng away, It is not beste it abide. It sittis youe to sette it aside, And sette Ã¾at he saide in his sawe, As he Ã¾at was prente full of pride, âJewes kyng am I,â comely to knawe, Full playne. Pil. Quod scripci, scripci, ?one same wrotte I I bide Ã¾er-by, What gedlyng will grucche there agayne.

[Scene II] Calvary. 10. Jesus. Ãou man Ã¾at of mys here has mente, To me tente enteerly Ã¾ou take, On roode am I ragged and rente, Ãou synfull sawle, for thy sake, For thy misse amendis wille I make. My bakke for to bende here I bide, Ãis teene for thi trespase I take, Who couthe Ã¾e more kyndynes haue kydde than I? Ãus for thy goode I schedde my bloode, Manne, mende thy moode, For full bittir Ã¾i blisse mon I by. 11. Ma. Allas! for my swete sonne I saie, Ãat doulfully to dede Ã¾us is di?t, Allas! for full louely Ã¾ou laye In my wombe, Ã¾is worthely wight. Allas! Ã¾at I schulde see Ã¾is sight Of my sone so semely to see, Allas! Ã¾at Ã¾is blossome so bright Vntrewly is tugged to Ã¾is tree, Allas! My lorde, my leyffe, With full grete greffe, Hyngis as a theffe, Allas! he did neuer trespasse. 12. Jesus. Ãou woman, do way of thy wepyng, For me may Ã¾ou no thyng amende, My fadirs wille to be wirkyng, For mankynde my body I bende. Ma. Allas! Ã¾at Ã¾ou likes noght to lende, Howe schulde I but wepe for thy woo! To care nowe my comforte is kende, Allas! why schulde we twynne Ã¾us in twoo For euere? Jesus. Womanne, in stede of me, Loo John Ã¾i sone schall bee. John, see to Ã¾i modir free, For my sake do Ã¾ou Ã¾i deuere. 13. Ma. Allas! sone, sorowe and si?te, Ãat me were closed in clay, A swerde of sorowe me smyte, To dede I were done Ã¾is day. Joh. A! modir, so schall ?e noght saie, I praye youe be pees in Ã¾is presse, For with all Ã¾e myght Ã¾at I maye, Youre comforte I caste to encresse In dede. Youre sone am I, Loo, here redy, And nowe for-thy I praye yowe hense for to speede. 14. Ma. My steuen for to stede or to steere, Howe schulde I such sorowe to see, My sone Ã¾at is dereworthy and dere, Thus doulfull a dede for to dye. Joh. A! dere modir, blynne of Ã¾is blee, Youre mournyng it may not amende. Ma. Cleo. A! Marie, take triste vn-to Ã¾e, For socoure to Ã¾e will he sende Ãis tyde. Joh. Fayre modir, faste Hense latte vs caste. Ma. To he be paste, Wille I buske here baynly to bide. 15. Jesus. With bittirfull bale haue I bought, Ãus, man, all Ã¾i misse for to mende, On me for to looke lette Ã¾ou no?t, Howe baynly my body I bende. No wighte in Ã¾is worlde wolde haue wende, What sorowe I suffre for thy sake, Manne, kaste Ã¾e thy kyndynesse be kende, Trewe tente vn-to me Ã¾at Ã¾ou take, And treste. For foxis Ã¾er dennys haue Ã¾ei, Birdis hase ther nestis to paye, But Ã¾e sone of man this daye, Hase no?t on his heed for to reste. 16. Lat. a sin. If Ã¾ou be Goddis sone so free, Why hyng Ã¾ou Ã¾us on Ã¾is hille? To saffe nowe Ã¾i selffe late vs see, And vs now, Ã¾at spedis for to spille. Lat. a dex. Manne, stynte of thy steuen and be stille, For douteles thy God dredis Ã¾ou no?t, Full wele are we worthy ther-till, Vnwisely wrange haue we wrought i-wisse. Noon ille did hee, Ãus for to dye; Lord! haue mynde of me What Ã¾ou art come to Ã¾i blisse. 17. Jesus. For sothe, sonne, to Ã¾e schall I saie, Sen Ã¾ou fro thy foly will falle, With me schall dwelle nowe Ã¾is daye, In paradise place principall. Heloy! heloy! My God, my God, full free, Lama?abatanye, Whar-to for-soke Ã¾ou me, In care? And I did neuere ille Ãis dede for to go tille, But be it at Ã¾i wille. A! me thristis sare. 18. Gar. A drinke schalle I dresse Ã¾e in dede, A draughte Ã¾at is full dayntely dight, Full faste schall I springe for to spede, I hope I schall holde Ã¾at I haue hight. Caip. Sir Pilate, Ã¾at moste is of myght, Harke! Heely! now harde I hym crye, He wenys Ã¾at Ã¾at worthely wight In haste for to helpe hym in hye In his nede. Pil. If he do soo, He schall haue woo. An. He wer oure foo, If he dresse hym to do vs Ã¾at dede. 19. Gar. Ãat dede for to dresse yf he doo, In sertis he schall rewe it full sore; Neuere Ã¾e lees if he like it noght, loo, Full sone may he couere Ã¾at care. Nowe swete sir, youre wille yf it ware, A draughte here of drinke haue I dreste, To spede for no spence Ã¾at ?e spare, But baldely ye bib it for Ã¾e beste For-why; Aysell and galle Is menged with alle, Drynke it ?e schalle, Youre lippis, I halde Ã¾ame full drye. 20. Jesus. Ãi drinke it schalle do me no deere, Wete Ã¾ou wele Ã¾er-of will I none. Nowe, fadir, Ã¾at formed alle in fere, To thy moste myght make I my mone. Ãi wille haue I wrought in Ã¾is wone, Ãus ragged and rente on Ã¾is roode, Ãus doulffully to dede haue Ã¾ei done, For-giffe Ã¾ame be grace Ã¾at is goode, Ãai ne wote no?t what it was, My fadir, here my bone, For nowe all thyng is done, My spirite to Ã¾ee right sone Comende I in manus tuas. [Jesus dies.] 21. Mar. Now dere sone, Jesus so iente, Sen my harte is heuy as leede, O worde wolde I witte or Ã¾ou wente; Allas! nowe my dere sone is dede. Full rewfully refte is my rede, Allas! for my darlyng so dere. Joh. A modir, ?e halde vppe youre heede, And sigh no?t with sorowes so seere, I praye. Ma. Cleo. It dose hir pyne To see hym tyne, Lede we her heyne, Ãis mornyng helpe hir ne maye. [Exit John and the two Maries. 22. Caip. Sir Pilate, parceyue I you praye, Oure costemes to kepe wele ?e canne, To-morne is our dere sabott daye, Of mirthe muste vs meve ilke a mane. ?one warlous nowe waxis full wane, And nedis muste Ã¾ei beried be, Deluyer Ã¾er dede sir, and Ã¾ane Shall we sewe to oure saide solempnite In dede. Pil. It schalle be done, In wordis fone; Sir knyghtis, go sone, To ?one harlottis you hendely take heede. 23. Ão caytiffis Ã¾ou kille with Ã¾i knyffe, Delyuere, haue done, Ã¾ei were dede. Mil. Mi lorde I schall lenghe so Ã¾er liffe, Ãat Ã¾o brothelles schall neuere bite brede. Pil. Ser Longeus, steppe forthe in Ã¾is steede, Ãis spere, loo, haue halde in thy hande, To Jesu Ã¾ou rake fourthe I rede, And sted nou?t but stiffely Ã¾ou stande A stounde. In Jesu side Schoffe it Ã¾is tyde, No lenger bide, But grathely Ã¾ou go to Ã¾e grounde. [Longeus pierces Jesus' side. 24. Long. lat. O! maker vnmade, full of myght, O! Jesu so jentile and jente, Ãat sodenly has lente me my sight, Lorde! louyng to Ã¾e be it lente. On rode arte Ã¾ou ragged and rente, Mankynde for to mende of his mys, Full spitously spilte is and spente, Thi bloode lorde to bringe vs to blis full free. A! mercy my socoure, Mercy my treasoure, Mercy my sauioure, Ãi mercy be markid in me. 25. Cent. O! wondirfull werkar i-wis, Ãis weedir is waxen full wan, Trewe token I trowe Ã¾at it is Ãat mercy is mente vnto man. Full clerly consayue Ã¾us I can, No cause in this corse couthe Ã¾ei knowe, ?itt doulfull Ã¾ei demyd hym Ã¾an To lose Ã¾us his liffe be Ã¾er lawe, No ri?te. Trewly I saie, Goddis sone verraye, Was he Ã¾is daye, Ãat doulfully to dede Ã¾us is di?t. [Enter Joseph. 26. Jos. Ãat lorde lele ay lastyng in lande, Sir Pilate, full preste in Ã¾is presse, He saue Ã¾e be see and be sande, And all Ã¾at is derworth on deesse. Pil. Joseph Ã¾is is, lely no lesse, To me arte Ã¾ou welcome i-wisse, Do saie me Ã¾e soth or Ã¾ou sesse, Thy worthyly wille what it is Anone. Jos. To Ã¾e I praye, Giffe me in hye Jesu bodye, In gree it for to graue al alone. 27. Pil. Joseph sir, I graunte Ã¾e Ã¾at geste, I grucche no?t to grath hym in grave, Delyuer, haue done he were dreste, And sewe, sir, oure sabott to saffe. Jos. With handis and harte Ã¾at I haue, I thanke Ã¾e in faith for my frende, God kepe Ã¾e Ã¾i comforte to craue, For wightely my way will I wende In hye. To do Ã¾at dede He be my speede, Ãat armys gun sprede, Manne kynde be his bloode for to bye. [Enter Nichodemus. 28. Nicho. Weill mette, sir, in mynde gune [I] meffe For Jesu, Ã¾at juged was vn-jente, Ye laboured for license and leve, To berye his body on bente. Jos. Full myldely Ã¾at matere I mente, And Ã¾at for to do will I dresse. Nicho. Both same I wolde Ã¾at wente And lette not for more ne for lesse, For-why Oure frende was he, Faithfull and free. Jos. Ãerfore go we To berie Ã¾at body in hye. [They go to the cross. 29. All mankynde may marke in his mynde To see here Ã¾is sorowfull sight, No falsnesse in hym couthe Ã¾ei fynde, Ãat doulfully to dede Ã¾us is dight. Nicho. He was a full worthy wight, Nowe blemysght and bolned with bloode. Jos. ?a, for Ã¾at he maistered his myght, Full falsely Ã¾ei fellid Ã¾at foode I wene, Bothe bakke and side, His woundes wide; For-Ã¾i Ã¾is tyde Take we hym doune vs be-twene. 30. Nicho. Be-twene vs take we hym doune, And laie hym on lenthe on Ã¾is lande. Jos. Ãis reuerent and riche of rennoune, Late vs halde hym and halse hym with hande. A graue haue I garte here be ordande, Ãat neuer was in noote, it is newe. Nicho. To Ã¾is corse it is comely accordande, To dresse hym with dedis full dewe Ãis stounde. Jos. A sudarye Loo here haue I, Wynde hym for-thy, And sone schalle we graue hym in grounde. 31. Nicho. In grounde late vs graue hym and goo, Do liffely, latte vs laie hym allone; Nowe sauiour of me and of moo Ãou kepe vs in clennesse ilkone. Jos. [Prays]. To thy mercy nowe make I my moone, As sauiour be see and be sande, Ãou gyde me Ã¾at my griffe be al gone, With lele liffe to lenge in Ã¾is lande, And esse. Nicho. Seere oynementis here haue I Brought for Ã¾is faire body; I anoynte Ã¾e for-thy With myrre and aloes. 32. Jos. Ãis dede it is done ilke a dele, And wroughte is Ã¾is werke wele i-wis. To Ã¾e kyng on knes here I knele, Ãat baynly Ã¾ou belde me in blisse. Nicho. He highte me full hendely to be his A nyght whan I neghed hym full nere; Haue mynde lorde and mende me of mys, For done is oure dedis full dere Ãis tyde. Jos. Ã¾is lorde so goode, Ãat schedde his bloode, He mende youre moode, And buske on Ã¾is blis for to bide.
